title: Bilateral Chronic Otitis Media and Cholesteatoma History
chief_complaint: I have some difficulty hearing, but I've adjusted to it since I've had it for so long. My main concern is maintaining the hearing I have left, especially since I go to places with high noise levels.

problem_summary.course: Chronic, with multiple surgeries over the years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of ear infections, cholesteatoma, tympanic membrane perforation.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Right ear hearing is poorer than the left. Previous hearing aid use in the right ear (3 years ago) was unsuccessful.

history.present_illness: Patient reports lifelong ear infections and problems. He feels he has adjusted to the loss but perceives the right ear as worse than the left.
history.otologic_history: Multiple otosurgeries bilaterally. Right ear: Revision canal wall down mastoidectomy with ossicular chain reconstruction (total ossicular replacement) ~1 year ago; tympanostomy tube placed in reconstructed middle ear. Left ear: Long-standing large tympanic membrane perforation.
history.noise_exposure_history: Reports going to places with high noise levels.
history.prior_management: Attempted amplification in the right ear 3 years ago; did not perceive benefit and the aid no longer fits the reconstructed ear.
history.patient_goals: Monitor stability of hearing and discuss hearing protection.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right Ear: Moderately severe to mild conductive loss (250-4000 Hz), sloping to moderate/moderately severe at high frequencies. Left Ear: Mild conductive loss rising to slight mixed loss (500-2000 Hz), sloping to mild conductive loss at high frequencies. Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally. Bone conduction thresholds are generally within normal limits.

numeric_results.Masking_Note: Unable to mask for left bone conduction thresholds at 1,000 and 2,000 Hz due to over masking.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

numeric_results.Reason_RE: Surgical history and presence of PE tube

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral conductive pathology, significantly asymmetrical with the right ear being worse. The right ear exhibits a moderately severe conductive hearing loss, while the left ear shows a mild conductive/mixed loss. Despite the degree of conductive loss, cochlear function (bone conduction) remains largely normal, and word recognition ability is excellent in both ears when speech is loud enough.
counseling_points: Since your main concern is protecting the hearing you have, we need to discuss custom hearing protection for when you are in noisy environments.
Your hearing test shows that your inner ear nerve function is actually quite good, but the mechanical parts (eardrum/bones) are preventing sound from getting through efficiently.
Because of your history of surgeries and the perforation in the left ear, we cannot perform the pressure test (tympanometry) today.
We recommend annual hearing tests to monitor for any changes.
Continue following up with your otologist as scheduled.
notes_for_actor: You are young (22) and have dealt with ear issues your whole life, so you are somewhat resigned to having 'bad ears'.
You are not currently interested in hearing aids because the last one didn't work well and didn't fit your surgically altered ear.
You are specifically worried about loud noise making your hearing worse.
